prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking whether the person who wrote the story (the author) is in the wrong. The situation is that the husband set up his office in the bedroom despite the wife's suggestion to use the basement. Now, he's on calls and the wife can't do anything because she has to keep the kids from disturbing him. She's also handling most of the housework and work from home tasks. She told him she can't guarantee silence in the bedroom, so he's upset, but she thinks he's wrong for not using the basement.

First, I need to figure out if the author is in the wrong. The husband chose the bedroom despite the wife's recommendation. She's trying to manage the household, work, and kids. The problem arises because he's in the bedroom, which restricts her movement. She made a deal that if he's in the basement, they won't disturb him, but in the bedroom, she can't promise that. So, he's choosing a location that causes conflict.

The key points here are: the husband's choice to work in the bedroom despite being offered a better alternative (basement), the impact on the wife's ability to do her tasks, and the fact that she communicated her concerns. The husband is not respecting her need for space and autonomy. The author is standing her ground, saying that she can't control the environment in the bedroom if he's there. So, the husband might be in the wrong for not compromising. Therefore, the author is not in the wrong. Answer B.
